title: How long does it take to get a PhD degree from high school until the end? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the US an undergraduate degree will require 4–5 years. After that, if the student is accepted into a medical school, they will have another 4 years there. After med school, they’ll still have to complete a residency and possibly one or more fellowships before they can truly begin working as a board-certified physician. The residency and fellowship take different amounts of time depending on the specialty - to work as a family physician might require only a few years as a resident and no fellowship; cardiology or neurosurgery might require another decade of work to complete. With regards to the degree itself - the US does not have a PhD in Medicine - some will earn a PhD and then an MD (or vice versa) while others will enroll in a combined MD/PhD program that takes 5–6 years. Other countries might do things differently. I met a woman from somewhere in Latin America who only spent 6 years between starting college and starting her practice as a dentist.

Just to avoid confusion, let me note that while medical schools do award PhDs, the degree that practicing physicians hold (in the US) is an MD. The admissions requirements for the two programs are sufficiently different that if you want to have the option of going after either of them, you need to start planning early. In either case, you’ll need to finish a bachelor’s degree first. This usually takes four years, although it may be possible to finish slightly more quickly. A PhD in medicine generally takes 5–6 years, but it’s possible that it will take longer. It’s very rare for someone to be eligible for a professorship immediately after that, so most people who want to continue in academia will take a series of short-term research positions to build up their profile. Others drop out and go to industry. An MD takes four years, but there’s extra training post-graduation. I know that everyone has to go through a three year residency, but I’m not sure if that’s the end of training for anyone. Specialists definitely have to go through extra training after that.

Mine was 8 years—4 for an undergraduate degree and 4 to wrap up my PhD research. However, my case is unusual, and it’s more common for a PhD these days to take 5–6 years in the US. It used to be shorter in the past and all the professors I worked with finished theirs in 3–4 years, but this is far less common today than it was >20 years ago. Another common route is undergraduate to a master’s (2 years) and then a PhD, which is a total of 10-11 years, although taking 12+ years isn’t too uncommon. How quickly you finish depends on luck and on your self-awareness. If you find the perfect adviser for you and a great topic that suits your ability and temperament, then you can finish fast and also do a very impactful PhD. But if you don’t know your strengths and flounder around for a bit while you learn about yourself, then it will take longer. And I would advise against prioritizing speed of completion over quality of work. Create something that you’re proud of. It shows, and makes getting a job much easier.

I just responded to someone (perhaps the same person because of the use of the phrase “until the end”) about long it takes for the JD. That answer was seven years. This time, the answer is not as certain. Four years (hopefully) for a bachelor’s degree. Two years (typically) for a master’s degree. 4–5 years (or more) for a PhD. … for a total of 10–11 years (or more) after high school. Sometimes, you can skip your master’s degree and go directly into a PhD program. In such a case you might save a year. As I said in my previous answer, that’s not the end; it’s just the beginning of your career (sometimes after a post-doc).

It varies depending on the school and the student. Bachelors degree is typically four years after high school. Masters is typically one to three years after completing a Bachelors. Two years is more typical. PhD is three to five years after that. First year is likely filled with course work and that’s followed by your comprehensive exam, research, and then writing and defending your thesis. I do know people who have taken significantly longer than 5 years tho.

response.answer_text: Minimum is 4 years of college and 4 for a PhD although some can cut a year off both. In my day it was 4 and 4 although I had a few fellow grad students who did a PhD in 3. My PhD program was almost entirely research based so when you had acquired the skills and could do a respectable dissertation you were good to go. No one bothered with a Masters degree. Today a PhD is more likely to be for 5 or more years — research skills are more complex and many students stay in grad school to accumulate publications before they try to get a job. As others have pointed it it varies with the school and the type of program. Typically degrees in the humanities take longer.

The fastest person through the lab where I studied, was 6 years 8 months including 4 years as an undergraduate. He went on to Post Doc in Berkley and made full professor in a leading university in very short order. For me it took somewhat longer. I started my primary degree in the seventies, and it took me about eleven years part-time to complete a masters and Ph.D. which I received in 2002 I think. I’m still studying.

I think you can plan on 8 or 10 years. Minimum. after high school. For some it is longer. Some students wind in and out of jobs along the way. Some get married, start families, etc. and never complete. But many do actually complete the long march. It takes commitment, and usually a willing spouse.

response.answer_text: A US bachelor’s degree normally takes about four years. A masters will normally take two years. A doctorate must normally be completed within eight years. There are some details: Some bachelor’s degrees can go faster if the student has transfer credits from dual enrollment, community college summer sessions, Advanced Placement testing, or CLEP tests.Some bachelor’s degrees take longer, especially if the student takes remedial courses, a double major, or study abroad. In addition, students may not be able to take their prerequisite courses when it is best for them. They may need to take a summer term or stay for a fifth year to complete all required coursework.Not all doctorates require a master’s degree.

Typically it takes about ten years, but can vary from 7 (almost never) to 12 or more. However, there is nothing magical about a PhD. That’s the starting line. Then you need to do a post-doc for 3 up to an indeterminate number of years before you are considered a member of the club.

There is no such thing as a PhD degree in law. People who go to law school need only to get the first degree in law called J.D. (Juris Doctor) and that’s all you need to take the bar exam or to teach.
